transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Hello, everyone.
Welcome here in Bogota.
And thank you for coming.
I'm Atila, and I'm from the Swarm Foundation.
And today I'm going to talk about the Swarm,
the where the project is at the moment,
how you can run a light node, how you can run a full node,
and talk a bit about future plans as well.
So I don't know how many of you are familiar with Swarm,
but basically Swarm is decentralized data storage
and distribution technology.
So also, I'm not sure how much of you
are familiar with this original idea of Ethereum
being the word CPU, but that's the Swarm origins coming
from the same time.
And then at that time, there was this idea
of this Holy Trinity, where Ethereum is the word CPU,
Swarm would be the word hard drive,
and then this would have been the messaging system.
And things turned out to be differently,
but still the idea and the roots of Swarm
is coming from that.
So you can think of Swarm as being a huge hard drive
based on peer-to-peer technology.
And then when I'm talking about Swarm,
people usually ask me, OK, so how is it
different from IPFS?
Like, this is the question that everyone is interested in.
And then it's quite different, but since the goals
of the projects are similar, then I
think it's worth mentioning, like, what
are the some kind of core ideas that are built into Swarm
and maybe differentiating with different or alternative
decentralized storage systems.
So one thing is that Swarm has a very strong focus and privacy
preserving and being permissionless.
So it means that you, in order to upload to the Swarm
to this world hard disk, you don't have to have a node.
So that's a different.
For my IPFS, you have to have your node.
And I will talk about later a bit more the differences
in how the data is handled.
But then again, going forward on this list,
like Swarm being iterative means that it uses a lot of primitives,
like crypto primitives that are used in Ethereum.
And also the smart contracts it uses are running on EVM.
So it doesn't invent its own blockchain,
and it does not try to create that problem,
because that is solved by others.
And it's not the area of focus.
It has robust defenses against blocking or changing access,
so that this is kind of the thing that we
cause censorship resistance.
So once data is uploaded to the network,
as long as there is someone who wants to keep it on the network,
then nobody else can take it down from the network.
Or that's the idea.
And then I will talk about later where we are with that.
There is also a feature which is like auto scaling.
So because this is a distribution network as well,
the data is downloaded, then the copies are stored on nodes.
And therefore, it's available on more nodes,
so that it has this property that more people sharing
the same kind of data sets, the more copies
there are on the network, and that can help with CDN type
of functionalities.
There is integrity protection with content addressing,
but also there is mutable updates with signed chunks.
So you can have both of these things together,
and with that, you can think of also not only just storing
static data sets, but have data structures that
can be updated and can be used for application layers.
And eventually, it forgets data or content that
is no longer relevant to preserve.
So as I will explain, you have to pay in order
to get the data on the network.
And if nobody is paying for the data,
then it means that it's no longer relevant,
so it will be deleted.
So from this, you may get an initial impression.
And I will go to some details, but not in a very deep level,
because that's not the focus of this workshop.
It's going to be hands-on, so don't worry.
Just give a small introduction so that everybody
is on the same page.
So basically, when you upload data to the swarm,
what happens is that swarm takes the data,
splits it into 4K chunks, and then assigns the--
yeah, and then optionally, currently, it's
optionally encrypt the chunks.
And then, based on the chunks, content address
finds the nodes that should be storing it on the network.
And that means that the data is spread on the network.
So then you want to upload a data,
assign data to the network.
Then when you have a node, then it
will find the nearest nodes that
matches the content address of the data, of the data chunk,
and send it there.
And then when you try to download the data,
the same logic happens.
So then, basically, you access any nodes,
and then it will find the route on the network,
and then get back the chunks from the nodes that
has the address closest to the chunks address.
And so that's the basics of the storing data on swarm
and the main concept.
And also, there are different kind of nodes.
So as swarm evolve, we realize that one size does not fit all.
And then, at the beginning, we only
had this full node functionality where the nodes were storing data.
It was also used for accessing the network
and basically all the functionality were in the full nodes.
But eventually, we realized that most people don't necessarily
need a full node functionality.
So we separated into different ways
how you can access the data on the swarm network.
There is a gateway that we provide as a free trial version.
So to speak, there is an ultra-light node,
which you can install on your laptop,
and then it doesn't use too much resources.
But then with that, you cannot upload to the network.
Because in order to upload to the network,
you will have to pay for the data, for someone to store it for you.
And that's something that you can do with a light node.
And I will install this on my computer.
We will see how the internet works.
So far, it was not always great.
But I hope someone like sacrificed some goats to the demo
gods today.
So that we can have some luck with that.
And yes, we basically realized that if you
want to see a web 2 kind of view of these different product
packaging, then I can show you this that basically there
is a free trial on the gateway that you can access
from the browser.
You don't need to install anything.
You can just go to this website.
You can upload it or download data,
but it's limited to certain size.
And then also that it's the nature of the gateways.
The gate way operators must comply with the low one,
then remove some data, and then at that point,
censorship resistance cannot be maintained or guaranteed.
If you want to access directly the network,
then the recommended way to do that
is by using either the swarm desktop app, which
is easy to install, and you can install it on your laptop
or desktop computers.
And then most-- we recommend this to most people
that want to create data and store network
or just want to simply access the data on the network.
And it comes into various like this root for light node,
which does not require you to do any kind of transactions
on the blockchain, but that's limited.
So then you can only access data, but not upload.
If you want to upload, you will have
to buy the swarm native token, which is called busy Z.
And then with that, you can buy capacity on the network
so that you can store your data.
And with the full node, it has the full functionality,
but it also means that you need to run this more likely
on a separate server.
Because if you run the full node on your laptop machine,
for example, it may use your network connection in times
that you don't want to.
It has to be around 24/7, because then that provides
the availability for the data for others on the network.
So if you close your laptop, then I
will talk about later, like, you wouldn't
be able to participate in the earning part of this thing.
So how you can earn money by storing data for other people.
And so, yeah, we realized that the full node is not
a very good choice for most people running it
on their laptops and stuff.
So for that, we recommend the desktop app and the full node.
We recommend people who are more seriously
want to store data for other people.
And then so maybe to recap like this,
like the light node considerations is lightweight.
You use only resources if you request them on demand.
So it doesn't have to go running 24/7.
And you can start without a penny.
So that means that you don't need to make any transactions
to start using it.
But later, you can unlock it with more functionality.
And the full node has different hardware requirements.
So currently, we recommend that you
can start running it on a Raspberry Pi with like 4G RAM, 70 gigs
of disk space.
It has to be an SSD.
So most likely, if you want to use a Raspberry Pi,
you have to connect your external SSD to that,
because it's quite demanding on the disk.
As a storage system should be.
It's all the way it's on.
So it's supposed to be run 24/7.
And you have to do one transaction in order
to participate in being a full node.
Basically, you have to deploy a checkbook contract
so that you can participate in something
that we call the bandwidth incentives.
So let me just talk a bit about that.
So basically, there are two kind of incentives.
There is bandwidth incentives.
That is like, incentives, like money
that you can earn for sharing the data on the network.
And then there's storage incentives.
That is like, you can earn by storing data for other people.
And so like everyone, maybe I don't
have to explain here the importance of incentives here.
But like maybe what's relevant here
is that like these two things are separate.
And currently, only the bandwidth incentives
are running on the mainnet.
So currently, you cannot really earn money
by storing data for other people.
This is something that we are working on currently.
And this is on testnet.
So we are planning to rolling it out like soon.
The testing is done.
And yeah, so maybe just to show you
like the data economy in the network
is that what we see is that what is interesting
is that consumers who are downloading data from the network
are actually paying for downloading data.
So there is a way to use it without paying.
But that means that your speed is limited
so that you don't--
basically, the nodes are prioritizing paying nodes
who are paying for downloading content.
And so the interesting thing here
is that this enables a new kind of economy.
So currently, the internet has this problem
that by storing data can be quite cheap.
But the problem is that if you try to store
large amount of data and it gets your project,
you get successful.
And people store downloading data from you,
then suddenly your costs are not on the storage side,
but actually on the bandwidth side.
So if you're using Amazon or something like that,
then you will have to pay a lot for the bandwidth.
And that can be-- for a small project,
that can be prohibitively expensive.
So storing-- I know I had this example that's storing 40
gigabytes for years, like few dollars maximum.
But if there are 10,000 people downloading that from you,
you can start paying money in the $10,000 range.
And then small projects may not be able to afford that.
And by changing these kind of dynamics
and making the downloaders pay can
enable new kind of applications where even small projects
can afford to host big data sets.
And also, this enables hosting public data sets
or common good data sets that we consider,
like, for example, Wikipedia data or open street maps data.
Or it would be good to see blockchain data.
It doesn't really make sense to blockchain data
be stored on all the nodes.
It would make sense to have one common good space
where everyone could finance and maintain as a common good.
And there are many other use cases that this can enable.
And what I see here is that this can create
this kind of new kind of applications where
business opportunities can rise, when data creators can
create something that is stored on swarm.
And then that can be shared with consumers.
And then here you can figure out, like, you upload data,
you get back the reference, and then
by giving access to that data can be turned
into business opportunities.
So that is also something that we considered solved problem.
And now I'm going to the more hands-on part of the workshop.
So I will go to the terminal and do some stuff that we
build as usually in the terminal.
And so the first thing I would like to talk about is that--
so the swarm currently has an implementation called B.
And you can download B from the website.
And you can install it on your computer.
And then you can configure it and start interacting with that.
And so there is a dev mode for this.
I wanted to show this to you because that's quite easy to use.
And it's quite handy when you are not sure if you want to be
invested in this.
And you don't want to spend too much time on that.
So basically, once you have the B binary installed
on your machine, which is called B then,
this dev mode can be just invoked with this B dev.
It starts up, and then it's ready to serve requests.
So you can access the B API on the port 1633.
And it also has some other functionality in ports 1635.
It's currently that data-related functionality can be accessed
on the 33 port.
And then administrative functions can be accessed on the 35.
And maybe I can show you the documentation for this.
So we have quite complete documentation.
So how the API works.
And then maybe I will do this at the end.
Once I went through all the things.
So I just wanted to show you that basically trying it
in dev mode can be quite easy.
And it does not take you a lot of time
if you just want to try to upload it or download it,
check out, fill the API then.
This is a recommended way to do.
And then there is a desktop app.
So for that, I will need to--

So there is this concept of Post-Tits stamps.
So when you have the money for uploading,
basically, the Post-Tits stamp is something
that you need to attach to your content.
And basically, it's two things.

So this is like the post-- we call it Post-Tits stamp,
and then you attach it.
I mean, it's far a message.
It's easy to all your data that you upload it.

And then, this is also used later for the redistribution

But it's like it would be good to share with someone,

But this is how it works.
It generates this hash.
You can just copy this hash and then share it with someone else,
and they can access the data with this hash from the network.
And it has some functionality where
you can manage your wallet, and your balance, and your checkbook.
So the checkbook is the thing that
is used for the bandwidth incentives.
So if you are running a full node, then this checkbook
is-- you don't necessarily have to put money in it.
But if you want to download big amount of data,
then you can basically make it faster
by putting money in the checkbook.
And then how it works is that when
your node is requesting data from another node,
then they create a balance between them.
And if your node is only downloading,
then your balance will be negative.
So then eventually you have to settle that balance,
and then you can do this with the checkbook.
And if you have a full node, you don't necessarily
have to do this because the full nodes are participating
in sharing the data.
And then basically, over time, your balance will even out.
So you can also do that if you want
to use your full node for uploading data as well.
But it's not necessarily to do that.
And then we have these post-distants.
And then here you can see the statistics of post-distant
manage post-distants.
Like, the idea for this is that you can basically
create different kind of content, what you want to share
and for how long.
And then for those different kind of categories,
you can create different kind of post-distants
and upload the data according to this category.
And there are also features called feeds.
So this is the thing that I talked about.
These mutable chunks are mutable data with signed chunks.
It enables you to create a version that
can be updated over time.
And then with that, you can hear in this UI.
You can even use that as a-- for example,
if you upload your website, then the basic model
where you upload it will be like you
will get the content hash of the data that you uploaded.
But that will change over time as you change your website.
So if you want to avoid the paying the cost for updating
your website every time in ENS and then
point it to a different ENS record
and pay the transaction cost for that,
you can use this feeds functionality
and then basically update your feed.
And then your feed will also have fixed.
Like not changing hash that you can put in ENS.
And with that, you can update your website through the feeds.
And that, for that, you don't need
to change the cost on the blockchain.

And then it's much better just to start your node with an

Because currently, there are ways to secure your wallet.
So SWARM also uses a thing that maybe familiar from running

But we found, actually, that was one of the source of the

So the swap endpoint is maybe it has this

So initially we had this, the swap is called bandwidth

And for that, you need an RPC endpoint.
And I just added one.
It's a public endpoint, but obviously you can use, like,
on the Gnosis chain, it's like you can use GetBlock or
whatever provider you want to use, or you run your own
node, of course.
But so this is an RPC endpoint to access the blockchain.
And you also need an initial deposit.
Config variables, so by default it's not zero, because

their check.
This is for the checkbook.
So in order to have some balance, but we found out that in

And if you don't want to use your full node for uploading or

In order to do that, though, there is an initial
transaction.
If you want to run a full node, it deploys a checkbook
contract.
And for that, you will need some x-dial in order to make
the transaction.
But that's the only initial cost that you will need.
And there is this thing which is documented also that you
can fine-tune your B node to increase the default number of
open files, which is something that Unix system have, like
basically the open files can be open files, but also the
network connections in Unix are represented as files.
And then we use quite a few network connections, so it's
better to increase the default values.
And then one more option is this resolver options, which is

So there is ENS integration of Swarm that if you have an

You can set it to your Swarm address, and then it will

And since this is happening on the Eternal Mainnet, this

So this is a kind of trade-off, and this is also optional.
And this one, this last option is only needed if you want to
enable the debug API.
